title: 114_hr2712
content: The "Commonsense Reporting and Verification Act of 2015" includes provisions for a prospective reporting system, protection of dependent privacy, electronic statements, GAO studies, and an eligibility verification process for ACA subsidies. The Act may be cited as the "Commonsense Reporting and Verification Act of 2015". The "Commonsense Reporting and Verification Act of 2015" includes findings by Congress regarding minimizing compliance burdens and protecting privacy under the Affordable Care Act. It also establishes a prospective reporting system. The Act mandates the implementation of a voluntary prospective reporting system by the Secretary of the Treasury within 180 days. Employers can report their information voluntarily, including name, employer identification number, and certification of coverage. Employers can voluntarily report their information, including name, employer identification number, and certification of coverage offered to employees, dependents, spouses, and part-time employees. Employers must report information on coverage offered to part-time employees, meeting minimum value requirements, and satisfying affordability safe harbors. They also need to report the availability of coverage to full-time employees and any applicable waiting periods, due 60 days before the start of the reporting period. The information to be reported includes coverage availability for full-time employees, any waiting periods, and a process for secure access to information by Exchanges, the Data Services Hub, and the IRS for eligibility determinations. The curr_chunk describes the process for agencies to provide necessary information for eligibility determinations of premium tax credits and cost-sharing subsidies under the Affordable Care Act. It includes following up with employers for additional information and notifying employees of any eligibility issues. The curr_chunk outlines the process for employers to update the Federal Marketplace Data Services Hub with changes in coverage for employees. Employers who provide prospective reporting through the system will be exempt from certain reporting requirements under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Employers updating the Federal Marketplace Data Services Hub with coverage changes for employees will be exempt from certain reporting requirements under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This includes satisfying return requirements and furnishing statements to the IRS and employees as outlined in the Code. Employers can use third parties to complete filing for employee health plan enrollment under the Affordable Care Act without affecting their liability under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Employers can utilize third parties for filing employee health plan enrollments under the Affordable Care Act without impacting their liability under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Exchanges must notify employers when an employee or dependent enrolls in a qualified health plan through the Exchange. SEC. 4 amends Section 6055(b) of the Internal Revenue Code to allow substitution of name and date of birth for TINs for dependents if not collected before 2014. The effective date is 60 days after enactment. SEC. 5 pertains to electronic statements. Section 6056(c) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow electronic delivery of statements if consented to by the individual. Similarly, Section 6055(c) is amended to allow electronic delivery of statements relating to health insurance coverage. The amendments made by this section allow for electronic delivery of statements relating to health insurance coverage if consented to by the individual. The effective date for these amendments is after December 31, 2015. SEC. 6. GAO STUDIES. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study evaluating employer notifications by Exchanges under the Affordable Care Act regarding full-time employees eligible for tax credits or subsidies. The Comptroller General of the United States will evaluate employer notifications by Exchanges under the Affordable Care Act regarding full-time employees eligible for tax credits or subsidies, including data elements, notification process, employer feedback, and total notifications sent. The evaluation will include decisions on appeals, total notifications sent to employers, differences between Federal and State-Based Marketplaces, challenges in the notification process, and recommendations. It will also assess if a separate appeals process for employers has been established by the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The Comptroller General will submit a report to relevant committees on the results of a study regarding challenges in the notification process for employers under the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act. Additionally, a study of a prospective reporting system will be conducted. The Comptroller General will conduct a study evaluating the prospective reporting system established under section 3, including the accuracy of information collected and challenges in implementation. The report will be submitted to relevant committees by July 1, 2018. The Comptroller General will submit a report to Senate and House committees by July 1, 2018, detailing the results of a study evaluating the prospective reporting system established under section 3, including challenges in implementation. ELIGIBILITY VERIFICATION PROCESS FOR ACA SUBSIDIES. A marketplace can automatically reenroll individuals in a qualified health plan annually, considering eligibility for subsidies and income changes. If the marketplace fails to follow the specified processes, reenrollment limitations apply. The section outlines reenrollment limitations for marketplaces regarding individuals' income information and eligibility for subsidies. It aligns with guidance from the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services on annual eligibility redeterminations and reenrollments for marketplace coverage. The Secretary will follow guidance on annual eligibility redeterminations and reenrollments for marketplace coverage, ensuring comprehensive rules for tax credits and cost-sharing reductions. Enrollees must maintain necessary information with the marketplace for automatic reenrollment in a qualified health plan. Enrollees eligible for automatic reenrollment in a qualified health plan must provide authorization for disclosure of information verifying eligibility for tax credits or cost-sharing reductions. The marketplace requests updated income information annually to confirm eligibility, and enrollees receive timely notices about redeterminations and reenrollments. The term "marketplace" refers to State Based Exchanges and the Federally Facilitated Exchange under the Affordable Care Act.
